message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient displays signs of agitation, bizarre behavior, elevated heart rate and blood pressure, and nasal bleeding, which are all consistent with cocaine intoxication. PCP intoxication may also cause similar symptoms, but nasal bleeding is less likely. THC intoxication does not typically cause aggressive or violent behavior. Thyrotoxicosis may cause agitation and elevated heart rate, but there are no other symptoms suggestive of hyperthyroidism.

The thin nasal mucosa oozing blood is also a sign of cocaine use. Phencyclidine (PCP) can cause similar symptoms, but it is less likely given the absence of horizontal and vertical nystagmus, which is a common physical exam finding in PCP intoxication. Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) intoxication generally does not cause symptoms as severe as those exhibited by the patient. Thyrotoxicosis may cause agitation and altered mental status, but it is less likely given the absence of symptoms such as weight loss, heat intolerance, and tremors.
